title: A Knight Templar abroad; or, Reminiscences of travel beyond the sea
author: Cord, W. Harlan.
snippet: Holyrood Chapel is all that remains of the old Abbey, and of the ancient structure nothing remains but the walls, the roof having fallen in many years since, and never having been restored ; but much of the architecture of the remaining portion of the venerable and historic ruin, is said by competent critics to belong to the architecture of a period much later.

title: Memorials of Edinburgh in the olden time
author: Wilson, Daniel
snippet: On the 5th of March 1562, an order appears for taking the stones of the chapel in the Nether Kirk-yard. This supplies the date of the utter demolition of Holyrood Chapel, as it was styled, which had most probably been spoiled and broken down during the tumults of 1559. It stood between the present Parliament House and the Cowgate ; and there, on the 12th of August 1528, Walter Chepman founded a chaplainry at the altar of Jesus Christ crucified, and endowed it with his tenement in the Cowgate.2

title: Memorials of Edinburgh in the olden time
author: Wilson, Daniel
snippet: Holyrood Chapel was now magnificently fitted up with richly carved stalls for the Knights of the Thistle. " An altar, vestments, images, priests, and their apurtcnts," arrived at Leith, by the King's yacht, from London, for the purpose of completing the restoration of the Abbey to its ancient uses.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :
author: Victoria
snippet: We drove in under Arthur's Seat, where the crowd began to be very great, and here the Guard of Royal Archers met us ; Lord Elcho walking near me, and the Duke of Roxburgh and Sir J. Hope on Albert's side. We passed by Holyrood Chapel, which is very old and full of interest, and Holyrood Palace, a royal-looking old place. The procession moved through the Old Town up the High Street, which is a most extraordinary street from the immense height of the houses, most of them being eleven stories high, and different families living in each story.

title: Stories of the Border Marches
author: Lang, John
snippet: While riding from Leith to Holyrood on March 27, 1682, his horse fell with him. His injuries proved fatal, and he died next day, and was buried in Holyrood Chapel.

title: Memorials of Edinburgh in the olden time
author: Wilson, Daniel
snippet: The news of the arrival of the Prince of Orange filled the Presbyterian party in Scotland with the utmost joy. The Earl of Perth, who was Chancellor, hastily quitted Edinburgh, and the mob made it the signal for an attack on Holyrood Chapel. A body of an hundred men defended it with firearms, which they freely used against their assailants, killing twelve of them, and wounding many more.

title: Philadelphians abroad.
author: [Conlen, William James]
snippet: Adjoining the palace was the ruined Holyrood Chapel, with the afternoon sun shining through its casements and making such a picture that we went outside to the hansom for our camera. In the midst of taking the picture we were apprehended by a guard who threatened to have us confined in the castle.

title: Rambles in Europe.
